This question really intrigued me, since I‚Äôve never given much thought to simplicity of dress. Clothes have always been such an important part of my self expression, and besides, my career (entertainment industry) mandates that I dress rather flashily. Other Quakers who also do my kind of work dress similarly.

I looked it up in my copy of Faith and Practice, the  Philadelphia Yearly Meeting book that‚Äôs basically about how to be a Quaker. It doesn‚Äôt say anything about simplicity of dress. The closest I could find was about environmental stewardship and violence, which I think speaks to your question because mass produced lace is so often made in sweatshops with tyrannical work policies and abysmal environmental practices.

I‚Äôm not going to claim to be an expert on this, especially since it‚Äôs not a rule I adhere to. That said, I think the best path forward is to be conscious of where your clothes are coming from and who makes them, and then making purchases that are ethically produced, such as from an ethical clothing company or secondhand. That way you‚Äôre being a good environmental steward and giving the most compassion towards workers.

Look, I‚Äôm tired, I checked your post history and you don‚Äôt seem like a bad person, and I still vehemently disagree with you, especially as a queer trans mentally ill person, survivor of sexual assault, and all that good shit. Just... maybe consider it, be open to different points of view irl, listen to what leftists and radicalism‚Äôs (not just anarchists) in real life and not an internet echo chamber have to say. There‚Äôs... so much more riding on this than healthcare my dude. Black and brown people, LGBT+ people, women, would rather have someone less bad for the sake of their own humanity. Frankly you‚Äôre a shit ally if you think not listening to them/us, or your peers depending on your positioning, and doing fuck all with your vote is a good idea. Even with major political issues like, yes, healthcare, gun reform, immigration, foreign policy, I‚Äôd rather have it be a little tiny bit better than not better at all or worse. I don‚Äôt know how to explain to you that you should care about other people
Consider: I‚Äôd rather have a less evil candidate in office and then work to overthrow the system. These things aren‚Äôt mutually exclusive. You‚Äôre being thick.
Consider: your third party is never going to win and, if given the choice, I‚Äôd rather have less evil than more evil
Vote. It‚Äôs beyond privileged to have the ability to opt out. A less bad candidate is still, y‚Äôknow, less bad, even if he‚Äôs terrible.

The accidentals might be doable (I‚Äôm not sitting at my harp rn to check) but I‚Äôm also really concerned about the spacing. The harp is not a piano, so a lot of what‚Äôs going on there (fast, wide, big jumps, occasional 3rds thrown in) is going to be virtually impossible. I would suggest orchestrating it for two harps and splitting between the bass / treble ranges ‚Äî two harps is always better than one anyway!

If there‚Äôs a harpist at your school, I highly suggest reaching out to buy them dinner (or coffee, or a really great slice of cheesecake) and asking them to look through it. Nothing beats a harpist in real life actually looking at your harp part and offering suggestions. If you do research on all the major harp composers, they were either harpists, had harpists fix the parts with no credit (looking at you, Tchaikovsky), or had a harpist colleague they worked closely with. Good luck!

I feel this so deeply. Because I live far away from my uBPD mom, effectively gray rock-ing (and maintaining my boundaries without actually verbalizing them) means she doesn‚Äôt have outbursts anymore, unless there‚Äôs something extremely difficult going on in her life and she‚Äôs taking it out on me or my partner. That said, even though I‚Äôve found a (mostly) workable solution, I still remember what she can be like, so I have to keep my boundaries. Which feels completely horrible. I know it‚Äôs okay to say no and to have my limits, even more okay after all the shit she put me through, but I also can‚Äôt help but see her as a lonely old woman with a crippling mental illness who needs help. Help I can‚Äôt give.

I don‚Äôt verbalize my boundaries because it will end in a fight but here are some of mine: she doesn‚Äôt know about my private feelings, only feelings I would tell anyone. I only call on weekends to catch up- she‚Äôs hard to contact so I‚Äôll call a few times across the weekend. If she doesn‚Äôt answer she can call me, I‚Äôm not chasing her down. Conversations are capped at an hour.  Her ringtone is silent and her texts are muted. I schedule breaks for myself when we see each other in person. No touching unless I have to for some reason.
What on earth could she want though? I literally have nothing

I think that would be a good first step so you can have a trusted adult on your side and help you weigh your options, find resources, etc.

ETA much love and respect to those suggesting school social workers- I didn‚Äôt have much luck with mine when I was in high school, but I really, really hope that was an isolated incident.
